lines.text: Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV, GLOUCESTER, HASTINGS, and Soldiers

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Now, brother Richard, Lord Hastings, and the rest, Yet thus far fortune maketh us amends, And says that once more I shall interchange My waned state for Henry's regal crown. Well have we pass'd and now repass'd the seas And brought desired help from Burgundy: What then remains, we being thus arrived From Ravenspurgh haven before the gates of York, But that we enter, as into our dukedom?

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: The gates made fast! Brother, I like not this; For many men that stumble at the threshold Are well foretold that danger lurks within.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Tush, man, abodements must not now affright us: By fair or foul means we must enter in, For hither will our friends repair to us.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: My liege, I'll knock once more to summon them.
Enter, on the walls, the Mayor of York, and his Brethren

lines.speaker: mayor
lines.text: My lords, we were forewarned of your coming, And shut the gates for safety of ourselves; For now we owe allegiance unto Henry.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: But, master mayor, if Henry be your king, Yet Edward at the least is Duke of York.

lines.speaker: mayor
lines.text: True, my good lord; I know you for no less.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Why, and I challenge nothing but my dukedom, As being well content with that alone.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: [Aside]  But when the fox hath once got in his nose, He'll soon find means to make the body follow.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: Why, master mayor, why stand you in a doubt? Open the gates; we are King Henry's friends.

lines.speaker: mayor
lines.text: Ay, say you so? the gates shall then be open'd.
They descend

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: A wise stout captain, and soon persuaded!

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: The good old man would fain that all were well, So 'twere not 'long of him; but being enter'd, I doubt not, I, but we shall soon persuade Both him and all his brothers unto reason.
Enter the Mayor and two Aldermen, below

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: So, master mayor: these gates must not be shut But in the night or in the time of war. What! fear not, man, but yield me up the keys; For Edward will defend the town and thee, And all those friends that deign to follow me.
Takes his keys
March. Enter MONTGOMERY, with drum and soldiers

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Brother, this is Sir John Montgomery, Our trusty friend, unless I be deceived.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Welcome, Sir John! But why come you in arms?

lines.speaker: montague
lines.text: To help King Edward in his time of storm, As every loyal subject ought to do.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Thanks, good Montgomery; but we now forget Our title to the crown and only claim Our dukedom till God please to send the rest.

lines.speaker: montague
lines.text: Then fare you well, for I will hence again: I came to serve a king and not a duke. Drummer, strike up, and let us march away.
The drum begins to march

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Nay, stay, Sir John, awhi le, and we'll debate By what safe means the crown may be recover'd.

lines.speaker: montague
lines.text: What talk you of debating? in few words, If you'll not here proclaim yourself our king, I'll leave you to your fortune and be gone To keep them back that come to succor you: Why shall we fight, if you pretend no title?

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Why, brother, wherefore stand you on nice points?

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: When we grow stronger, then we'll make our claim: Till then, 'tis wisdom to conceal our meaning.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: Away with scrupulous wit! now arms must rule.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: And fearless minds climb soonest unto crowns. Brother, we will proclaim you out of hand: The bruit thereof will bring you many friends.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Then be it as you will; for 'tis my right, And Henry but usurps the diadem.

lines.speaker: montague
lines.text: Ay, now my sovereign speaketh like himself; And now will I be Edward's champion.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: Sound trumpet; Edward shall be here proclaim'd: Come, fellow-soldier, make thou proclamation.
Flourish

lines.speaker: soldier
lines.text: Edward the Fourth, by the grace of God, king of England and France, and lord of Ireland,  and c.

lines.speaker: montague
lines.text: And whosoe'er gainsays King Edward's right, By this I challenge him to single fight.
Throws down his gauntlet

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: Long live Edward the Fourth!

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Thanks, brave Montgomery; and thanks unto you all: If fortune serve me, I'll requite this kindness. Now, for this night, let's harbour here in York; And when the morning sun shall raise his car Above the border of this horizon, We'll forward towards Warwick and his mates; For well I wot that Henry is no soldier. Ah, froward Clarence! how evil it beseems thee To flatter Henry and forsake thy brother! Yet, as we may, we'll meet both thee and Warwick. Come on, brave soldiers: doubt not of the day, And, that once gotten, doubt not of large pay.
Exeunt
